Replace Int Without Variable

Rapid overview
  • üßÆ 1Ô∏è‚É£ Method 1 ‚Äî Using Arithmetic (Addition & Subtraction)
  • ‚öôÔ∏è How it works
  • ‚ö†Ô∏è Caveat
  • ‚ö° 2Ô∏è‚É£ Method 2 ‚Äî Using Bitwise XOR
  • üß† How it works
  • ‚úÖ Pros
  • üîç 3Ô∏è‚É£ Comparison
  • üöÄ Interview Tip

Excellent interview-style question üí°

You can swap two integer values without using a third variable using either arithmetic operations or bitwise XOR.

Let‚Äôs go through both üëá

---

üßÆ 1Ô∏è‚É£ Method 1 ‚Äî Using Arithmetic (Addition & Subtraction)

int a = 5;
int b = 10;

a = a + b; // a = 15
b = a - b; // b = 5
a = a - b; // a = 10

Console.WriteLine($"a = {a}, b = {b}");

‚úÖ Output:

a = 10, b = 5

‚öôÔ∏è How it works

  • Step 1: a temporarily holds the sum of both.
  • Step 2: Subtracting b from sum gives original a.
  • Step 3: Subtracting new b gives original b.

‚ö†Ô∏è Caveat

  • Risk of integer overflow if a + b exceeds the data type‚Äôs range.

---

‚ö° 2Ô∏è‚É£ Method 2 ‚Äî Using Bitwise XOR

int a = 5;
int b = 10;

a = a ^ b;
b = a ^ b;
a = a ^ b;

Console.WriteLine($"a = {a}, b = {b}");

‚úÖ Output:

a = 10, b = 5

üß† How it works

XOR has a neat property:

  • x ^ x = 0
  • x ^ 0 = x
  • x ^ y ^ y = x

So:

  1. a = a ^ b ‚Üí combined info of a & b
  2. b = a ^ b ‚Üí becomes original a
  3. a = a ^ b ‚Üí becomes original b

‚úÖ Pros

  • No overflow risk
  • Works perfectly for integers

---

üîç 3Ô∏è‚É£ Comparison

| Method | Uses | Overflow Risk | Works For | Readability | | --------------- | -------- | ------------- | ------------- | -------------- | | Arithmetic | +, - | ‚ö†Ô∏è Yes | Numeric types | Moderate | | Bitwise XOR | ^ | ‚úÖ No | Integers only | Less intuitive |

---

üöÄ Interview Tip

If asked in an interview, say:

‚ÄúThere are two main ways ‚Äî arithmetic or bitwise XOR. XOR is safer because it avoids overflow and doesn‚Äôt need extra storage.‚Äù

---

Would you like me to explain why the XOR trick mathematically guarantees that the two values swap back correctly (bitwise reasoning)?
